details.title: Competing causes of failure and reliability tests for Weibull lifetimes under type I progressive censoring
details.standardTitle: Competing causes of failure and reliability tests for Weibull lifetimes under type I progressive censoring

p: Uditha Balasooriya received his B.A. and DipStat from the University of Sri Lanka; and his M.A. in Mathematics and Ph.D. in Statistics from the University of Western Ontario, Canada. His previous employments were at the University of Kelaniya, Sri Lanka, the National University of Singapore, and the Memorial University of Newfoundland, Canada. His research interests include life testing, reliability, statistical and actuarial modeling. He is a member of the Statistical Society of Canada, the American Statistical Association and the Singapore Institute of Statistics.

authors.affiliation: Nanyang Bus. Sch., Nanyang Technol. Univ., Singapore
authors.name: U. Balasooriya

p: C.-K. Low received his B.Ec.(Hons) and Ph.D. in Econometrics from the Monash University, Australia. Prior to joining Nanyang Technological University he had taught at the National University of Singapore. His research interests include statistical modeling, reliability, time series forecasting and actuarial modeling.

details.abstract: For many high reliability products where very few items are expected to fail during the test period, testing under normal conditions is not feasible. Further, the requirement for high reliability increases the need for test procedures which yield valuable degradation and other useful information for improving product reliability. Thus in some manufacturing and other experiments, various types of failure censored and accelerated life tests are commonly employed for life testing. In this paper we discuss Type I progressively censored variable-sampling plans for Weibull lifetime distributions under competing causes of failure. The proposed procedure is attractive as it yields useful degradation-related information for improving product quality. In addition, the procedure is useful when a test is conducted under severe time constraint and/or when the experimenter wishes to save costly specimens or scarce test facilities for other use.

links.abstract: This paper presents reliability sampling plans for the lognormal distribution based on progressively censored samples. In constructing these sampling plans, large-sample approximations to the best linear unbiased estimators of the location and scale parameters are used. For some selected progressive censoring schemes, reliability sampling plans are tabulated for p/sub /spl alpha// and p/sub /spl beta// to match MIL-STD-105. While in general, variable-sampling plans require smaller sample size wh...

context.text: Reliability sampling plans that are used to determine the acceptability of a product with respect to its lifetime under Type II progressive censoring (where the experiment is terminated when a fixed number of failures has been observed) have been considered recently by Balasooriya et al. [8] and Balasooriya and Balakrishnan [9].

references.text: U. Balasooriya, N. Balakrishnan, "Reliability sampling plans for the lognormal distribution based on progressively censored samples", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 49, pp. 199-203, 2000.

context.text: For the complete sample case, Herman and Patell [10] and Moeschberger and David [11] discussed maximum likelihood estimation under competing causes of failure.

references.text: A. V. Gajjar, C. G. Khatri, "Progressively censored samples from log-normal and logistic distributions", Technometrics, vol. 11, no. 4, pp. 793-803, 1969.

context.text: According to the well-known acceptance sampling procedure of Lieberman and Resnikoff [15], a lot is accepted if \${\mathhat \mu} - k {\mathhat \sigma} > L\$ where \$k\$ is known as the acceptance constant and \$L\$ denotes the one-sided lower specification limit imposed on the lifelength random variable under consideration (Note that in case of Weibull \$L\$ is the logarithm of the specification limit).

references.title: Sampling plans for inspection by variables
references.text: G. J. Lieberman, G. J. Resnikoff, "Sampling plans for inspection by variables", J. Amer. Stat. Association, vol. 50, pp. 457-516, 1955.

context.text: The Monte Carlo studies of Balasooriya et al. [8] and Schneider [16] on the accuracy of asymptotic normal approximation have shown that the procedure is sufficiently accurate for practical purposes.
Then, following the Lieberman and Resnikoff procedure (see also Schneider [16]), we can show that  and  where \$(p_{\alpha}, 1-\alpha)\$ and \$(p_{\beta}, \beta)\$ are the two points on the OC curve.

For \$1-\alpha =.95\$ and \$\beta =.10\$, the test plans are presented in Table I where following Schneider [16], \$p_{\alpha}\$ and \$p_{\beta}\$ values are chosen to match with MIL-STD-105D (US Military Standard sampling plans devised by the US Department of Defense, 1963).
Furthermore, in terms of the required sample size, the variable-sampling plans discussed in this paper are generally more efficient than attribute-sampling plans (see Schneider [16]).

references.title: Failure-censored variables-sampling plans for lognormal and weibull distributions
references.text: H. Schneider, "Failure-censored variables-sampling plans for lognormal and weibull distributions", Technometrics, vol. 31, no. 2, pp. 199-206, 1989.

links.abstract: The problem of evaluating the time-to-failure percentiles in progressively-censored tests on solid insulating materials is addressed. Statistical methods to estimate the parameters of the Weibull distribution (and their confidence limits) are examined on the basis of the results of aging with combined thermal-electrical stresses carried out on XLPE insulated cable models. These tests are performed at the same stresses on samples more than 1 m long and subjected to progressive censoring of aging ...

context.text: As reported in Montanari and Cacciari [17], in this progressively censored experiment live specimens \$R_{i} = 2\$, 1, 3, 1, 3, 2 were removed at selected times and/or at the time of breakdowns of order \$i = 1, \ldots, 6\$.
Consider the progressive censoring experiment of Montanari and Cacciari [17] discussed earlier in Illustration 1.

references.title: Progressively-censored aging tests on XLPE-insulated cable models
references.text: G. C. Montanari, M. Cacciari, "Progressively-censored aging tests on XLPE-insulated cable models", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 23, pp. 365-372, 1988.
